newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australia budget bill due in Senate Wednesday.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australia budget bill due in Senate Wednesday.

text.p: The Australian government said a key budget bill, to limit migrants' welfare entitlements, was due to be voted on early on Wednesday in the upper house of parliament, the Senate.
"It will probably be voted on in about an hour or an hour and a half," a spokesman for Social Security Minister Jocelyn Newman told Reuters on Wednesday.
"The substantial part of our amendments were accepted on Tuesday by the independents," the spokesman said.
"By approving that they have basically approved the vast bulk of what we were intending in the bill, and that was the A$200 million worth of savings over four years," he said.
Independents Mal Colston and Brian Harradine, who hold the balance of power in the Senate, voted against the bill late last year.
According to government estimates last year's amendments would cost savings of A$130 million in 1997/98, rising to A$400 million over four years.
Under the Social Security (Newly Arrived Residents' Waiting Periods) Bill, 1996, the government wants to exclude migrants from social security payments for two years after arrival.

A government gains the constitutional option of an early Senate election if the Senate fails to pass a bill in the form demanded by the House of Representatives and then does so again after three months.
This bill was last considered by the Senate less than two months ago.
